awd_titl_txt: NSF Workshop Proposal to Develop a Summer Institute for STEM Teachers and Curriculum Development for a Novel 6-12 Grade STEM Program for a School of Environmental & Coastal Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Louisiana State University's (LSU) will offer professional development to science teachers in a new school in East Baton Rouge Parish School System (EBRPSS). EBRPSS is developing a “focus choice” grades 6-12 school that is analogous to the LSU College of the Coast and Environment (CC&E). The goal is to develop a pre-college curriculum that will articulate with CC&E’s interdisciplinary Coastal Environmental Science B.S. Program, which is heavily underpinned with rigorous STEM courses. CC&E, in partnership with LSU’s College of Human Sciences and Education, will help develop curriculum focused on hands-on, place-based learning and provide EBRPSS teachers with professional development opportunities that enable them to master the material that they will teach.

The EBRPSS is fast-tracking this new environmental school and aims to begin with a first cohort of sixth grade students in the fall 2022 semester. LSU faculty will develop a two-week Summer Institute Workshop focusing on curriculum development and teacher professional development, as well as assistance leading up to the first day of classes in August. The new school is located 2.2 miles from the CC&E campus, and a neighboring school is 93% minority students. The new public school will educate a drastically underserved population, offer students a strong science foundation, and engage them in local environmental and geoscience topics. The overall aim of this “School of Environmental Studies and Coastal Studies” is to educate diverse cohorts of students who can matriculate directly to LSU, particularly in the College of the Coast and Environment’s Coastal Environmental Science B.S. degree, or in other LSU programs with an environmental focus.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

Louisiana State University was asked by the East Baton Rouge Parish School System (EBRPSS) to partner to develop a “focus choice” grades 6-12 school that is analogous to the LSU College of the Coast and Environment (CC&E). This program provides open access to all students but requires that students maintain established standards to remain in the program. The goals are to (1) develop a curriculum that will articulate with CC&E’s interdisciplinary Coastal Environmental Science B.S. Program, which is heavily underpinned with rigorous STEM courses. (2) develop curriculum focused on hands-on, place-based and phenomenon-based learning, and (3) provide EBRPSS teachers with professional development opportunities that enable them to master the material that they will teach, (4) deliver a two-week Summer Institute Workshop focusing on curriculum development, transdisciplinary phenomenon-based learning spanning science, English language arts, social studies, math, art and physical education and teacher professional development, as well as assistance creating the school leading up to the first day of classes in August.  

We started with a vision of creating an environmentally focused school where coast and environment is infused throughout curriculum in a transdisciplinary manner. Students also experience the joy of being a scientist and solving problems in their community through place-based learning (PBL). We wrote science curriculum enhancements using 21st Century Science Standards and the Louisiana State Science Standards. The EBRPSS has a partnership with Jason Leanring (www.jason.org) to develop support materials. We worked with Jason Learrning's curricular materials to encorporate them. Two weeks of professional development were conducted where all the teachers at the school practiced the new enhancements and then aligned the scope and sequence of their subjects with PBL. Using the thematic bases we identified during the alignment of the scope and sequence, we co-produced the framework for two PBL projects for 6th grade students.  

In August 2022 we started with sixth grade and will add each grade in the next few years. We want the students to identify as scientists and want to stir up their excitement in science. The goal is to create an educated workforce and informed voters who understand the importance of protecting the coast and environment. Students who graduate from Eva Legard gain automatic admission into LSU and College of Coast and Environment. 

To actualize this dream, educational standards were examined, and enhancements were created based on geosciences; we added to existing curriculum using this NSF grant. All the curriculum was intertwined with Phenomena-Based Learning (PhBL), and we identified themed Accelerated Reader books enhance literacy. The teachers participated in two weeks of Professional Development (PD) to learn the enhancements and create a framework for the PhBL. Problem-based learning, hands-on activities, and monthly environmentally focused field trips were intentionally pushed into the framework to enhance students’ understanding. Two public service Graduate Assistants from LSU helped implement PhBL and provide support to the teachers for the success of this program. 

Broader Impacts: Outcomes and Experiences  

Workshop experience. On the last afternoon of the workshop, the evaluators conducted semi-structured interviews with the participants. Initial analysis of the qualitative data (semi-structured interviews) revealed all participants clearly gleaned value from the training in a variety of ways. Teachers identified usefulness of collaborating with LSU faculty to generate ideas for projects. Second, they reflected on the training’s effectiveness in building relationships and rapport. Those responsible for designing non-STEM courses discussed how the workshop helped them generate ideas for integrating the school’s environmental science emphasis into non-STEM subject areas. In sum, the teachers’ comments suggest increased efficacy for collaboration and incorporation of the school’s focus across subjects.  

School year. Students engaged in PhBL and had opportunities participate in environmentally focused field trips. Additionally, they learned to throw a cast net and identified and measured fish - data used to teach ratios and equations.  Eva Legard students’ proficiency in math and English language arts has improved by 40% and 30%, respectively since August 2022. The school competed for one of six national awards and was named Samsung Climate Superstars.

 Additional benefits. Partnering with the EBRPSS and Jason Learning had collateral effects that help to affirm and support LSU's efforts to work more closely with K-12 schools on STEM education. First, the EBRPSS has agreed to provide ongoing support for LSU's participation in the form of modest support for Linda Bui and graduate students in the manner of the former NSF GK-12 program.For LSU's graduate students this has an additional benefit of encouraging them to take interest in the challenges of K-12 STEM education. We have also developed a K-12 STEM teacher certification for our M.S. degree in Environmental Sciences. Finally, AASA ("The School Superindendents' Association") held a workshop on the LSU campus specifically intended to learn about our work with the Eva Legard School. We anticipate that other districts willl soon consider establishing a similar "focused choice" program.
